[[MTVph]] | terr serv 1 = [[DTTV|Digital]] | terr chan 1 = Channel 22 (Manila) (LCN: 22.04) | terr serv 2 = [[Easy TV (Philippines)|EasyTV Home]] | terr chan 2 = Channel 3 | sat serv 1 = [[Cignal]] | sat chan 1 = Channel TBA | sat serv 2 = SatLite | sat chan 2 = Channel TBA | sat serv 3 = [[G Sat]] | sat chan 3 = Channel TBA | cable serv 1 = [[Cablelink]] | cable chan 1 = Channel 58 | online serv 1 = Solar WatchNow | online chan 1 = [http://watchnow.solarsports.com.ph Watch Live] (Philippines only) }} '''Solar Sports''' is a [[Philippines|Filipino]] 24-hour cable TV sports channel that is owned by the [[Solar Entertainment Corporation]], and based in [[Shaw Boulevard]], [[Mandaluyong|Mandaluyong City]], [[Metro Manila]], [[Philippines]]. The channel was launched on January 1, 1994 and is available for [[Cablelink]] and contract for local cable operators and via livestreaming. ==History== The channel is known for showing sports that are familiar to the Filipinos. Its main programming are the NBA games, which are shown either a game or a doubleheader each day during the season. Other NBA programming includes shows produced by [[NBA TV]], such as the NBA's Greatest Games and [[Women's National Basketball Association|WNBA]] games during the league's off-season. It also shows the American [[Super Bowl]]. It is also the Filipino provider of the [[Olympic Games]]. It also shows boxing matches such as the ones from the promotions of [[Bob Arum]], [[Don King (boxing promoter)|Don King]] and most recently, [[Oscar de la Hoya]]'s Golden Boy Promotions. From 2002-2006, Solar Sports would cover the fights of [[Manny Pacquiao]], until Pacquiao signed with [[ABS-CBN]] for the rights to cover his fights. However, Solar Sports regained the broadcast rights for Pacquiao's fights since 2007 when the channel signed a deal with GMA Network. Other sports include [[Volleyball]] and [[Badminton]], such as the JVC Badminton tournament and the first-ever Manny V. Pangilinan Badminton Tournament, pitting players from Asia and Europe, in 2005. The network also launched ''[[Sports Desk (2004 TV series)|Solar Sports Desk]]'', a late-evening sports news program, similar to those famed American sports programs such as ''[[SportsCenter]]''. On October 2006, Solar Sports re-launch its channel, adding local shows. The channel is available exclusively in Metro Manila through Global Destiny Cable as of 2008. It used to be available exclusively on Sky Cable, but the two parties ceased their partnership at end of 2007 but it will be back on July 1. All cable companies in the provinces can put the channel without having to worry about exclusive rights. On April 10, 2017 [[Sky Cable]] & [[Destiny Cable]] dropped Solar Sports along with sister channels [[Basketball TV]], [[CT (TV channel)|CT]], [[Jack TV]] & [[NBA Premium TV]] allegedly due to Sky Catherine Bérubé | narrated = | country = Canada | network = [[CBC Television|CBC]] | first_aired = {{start date|2008|1|9}} | last_aired = {{end date|2009|3|23}} | num_seasons = 2 | num_episodes = 32 | list_episodes = List of Sophie episodes | website = http://www.cbc.ca/sophie/ }} '''''Sophie''''' is a [[Canada|Canadian]] [[television sitcom]] that aired on [[CBC Television|CBC]] from January 9, 2008 to March 23, 2009. It stars [[Natalie Brown (actress)|Natalie Brown]] as Sophie Parker, an unmarried single mother and talent agent. The show is an [[Canadian English|English-language]] [[adaptation]] of [[Télévision de Radio-Canada]]'s show ''[[Les Hauts et les bas de Sophie Paquin]]''. The show was created by [[Richard Blaimert]] and its [[executive producer]] is Jocelyn Deschênes, the same creative team behind the original series. It was the CBC's second attempt in as many years to create an English adaptation of a successful series from its French sister network, following the less successful ''[[Rumours (TV series)|Rumours]]''.[http://www.publicairwaves.ca/index.php?page=1967&PHPSESSID=94e09c9. Our Public Airwaves.ca - CBC TV tries again to adapt French comedy] In February 2008, it was announced that the show had been bought by [[ABC Family]], part of [[Disney-ABC Television Group]] in the [[United States]]. The network signed on for the first 13 episodes, as well as an option for the second season of the show.[http://www.cbc.ca/arts/tv/story/2008/02/05/sophie-abc.html ABC Family buys CBC comedy Sophie] CBC News, February 5, 2008 On March 27, 2009, the series was cancelled by CBC due to poor ratings.[http://www.jam.canoe.ca/Television/2009/03/27/8911736-cp.html 'Sophie' was canceled due to low ratings] {{webarchive |url=https://archive.is/20090329045858/http://www.jam.canoe.ca/Television/2009/03/27/8911736-cp.html |date=March 29, 2009 }} ==Characters== * '''Sophie Parker''' ([[Natalie Brown (actress)|Natalie Brown]]) is a businesswoman and single mother who runs her own talent agency. Just hours after being told by a psychic that she was about to have the worst year of her life, her boyfriend Rick ran off with her best friend Melissa while Sophie was still pregnant with what she and Rick thought was Rick's baby. Soon afterward, she gave birth and discovered that the baby (named Robert) couldn't be Rick's child after all: he's half [[Black people|black]]. It turns out Robbie was conceived in a one-night stand Sophie had with André (played by [[Lyriq Bent]] in flashbacks), whom she met in a cab in [[New York City]]. At first, she did not have any contact with him and went as far as shredding his business card. But in the first season finale, he would later show up to see her, and upon learning that he was a father, he walked out on Sophie and left her devastated, only to return hours later to see Sophie with her ex-boyfriend Rick at her apartment. * '''Rick Ryder''' ([[Sebastian Spence]]) is Sophie's ex-boyfriend and former business partner who now runs his own competing talent agency which stole most of Sophie's clients. Despite the end of their relationship, however, they can't seem to get away from each other, in part because Sophie's mother is constantly plotting to reunite them. His continued presence in Sophie's life also complicates her efforts to find a new boyfriend: in one episode, he accidentally sees Melissa giving Sophie's current love interest a few pointers on how Sophie likes to be flirted with, mistakes him for someone ''Melissa'' is seeing behind his back, and later punches him in the face at a gallery show. In the first season finale, he almost asked Melissa to marry him, but when that failed he saw Sophie crying over being rejected by André and as they were about to go get a drink, he sees André walking towards the two. * '''Melissa Bryant''' ([[Amy Lalonde]]) is Sophie's former best friend and Rick's current girlfriend. A bit ditzy, she still thinks of Sophie as a dear friend — even helping her to line up dates and begging her to dogsit — and is unaware of how much she hurt Sophie by stealing Rick. She dotes on her dog like a baby, sometimes giving it more attention and TLC than she gives Rick. In the first season finale, Rick tried to ask Melissa to marry him, only to have the two argue, resulting in Rick leaving and Melissa furious. * '''Matt Scott''' ([[Jeff Geddis]]) is Sophie's [[gay]] best friend and confidant. Although in a relationship with Verner, a [[Swiss people|Swiss]] immigrant, he is not entirely committed to it and also has an eye for Bernard, a waiter at the café where he and Sophie hang out, and eventually slept with. In the end, he did confess to Verner and eventually made up by going off to [[Switzerland]] together. * '''Judith Parker''' ([[Mimi Kuzyk]]) is Sophie's [[Psychological manipulation|manipulative]] [[control freak]] mother. She is determined to reunite Sophie and Rick, faking a [[suicide]] attempt so that she can insist that they take care of her together and deliberately interfering when Sophie dates anyone who isn't Rick. * '''Estelle Burroughs''' ([[Sara Botsford]]) is a pretentious and flighty actress who affects a [[Received Pronunciation]] English accent, and the only client of Sophie's agency who didn't defect to Rick's new firm (although Sophie wouldn't be upset if she did). She was also the mistress of Sophie's late father for many years (as Sophie tells Judith about why she was signed to the agency, "She came with the deal. He put it in the will."), complicating her professional relationship with Sophie, but at times comes through for her. In one episode, Estelle played a part in getting Sophie a sought-after client after she recognized Estelle from in a play called ''Learning Rainbows'' and was a fan of Estelle. She thinks of herself as a positive force in Sophie's life, which makes one of them. * '''Ophelia Burroughs''' (Chantelle Chung) is Estelle's teenage daughter, whom Estelle adopted from [[China]]. Ophelia has no love for Estelle whatsoever. * '''Bridget''' (Catherine Bérubé) is Sophie's scheming receptionist, constantly trying to angle her way into a more senior job with the agency. * '''Christian Parker''' ([[Tyler Hynes]]) is Sophie's younger brother. Recently paroled from prison, he is determined to exploit his family connections to launch his own [[reality show]] depicting his experience as an ex-con readjusting to life "on the outside". ==Episodes== {{further|List of Sophie episodes}} ==Production== On February 5, 2008, it was announced that [[United States|American]] broadcast rights to ''Sophie'' were purchased by [[ABC Family]], which aired the series in 2009.[http://www.thefutoncritic.com/news.aspx?id=20080501abcfamily01 From The Futon Critic (May 2 2008)] ABC Family marketed the series as "original programming", although earlier seasons had already aired in Canada. The show was pulled from the lineup early in its run due to poor ratings. On March 7, 2008, it was announced that CBC ordered a second season of the show.[https://www.theglobeandmail.com/servlet/story/LAC.20080308.CBC08/TPStory/TPEntertainment/Television/ "CBC axes Hockey Wives, jPod"]. ''[[The Globe and Mail]]'', March 8, 2008. The second season started broadcasting on October 1, 2008 and ended on March 23, 2009. ==DVD Releases== As of May 2009, no plans for any DVD releases of ''Sophie'' have been announced. ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== {{portal|Television in Canada}} * [http://www.cbc.ca/sophie/ CBC Television: ''Sophie''] * {{IMDb title|0947080}} * {{tv.com show|sophie-can|Sophie}} [[Category:2008 Canadian television series debuts]] [[Category:2009 Canadian television series endings]] [[Category:2000s Canadian sitcoms]] [[Category:CBC Television shows]] [[Category:ABC Family shows]] [[Category:Pregnancy-themed television programs]] [[Category:Television series about show business]] [[Category:Canadian LGBT-related comedy television series]] [[Category:2000s LGBT-related comedy television series]]

{{about|the annual festival}} {{Infobox recurring event |name = South by Southwest |image = SxSW logo.png |caption = The official logo for SXSW, 2017 |location = [[Austin, Texas|Austin]], [[Texas]], U.S. |years_active = {{age|1987|03|10}} |first = 1987 |founders = Roland Swenson, Louis Jay Meyers, Louis Black, Nick Barbaro |dates = March (dates vary but generally coinciding with [[University of Texas at Austin]] [[spring break]] and also usually includes [[St. Patrick's Day]]) |frequency = Annual |next = March 8–17, 2019 |attendance = SXSW Music: 28,119
SXSW Interactive: 30,621
SXSW Film: 16,297
SXSW EDU: 4,260
Other Exhibits/Parties: 152,000 |genre = [[Conference]] and [[festival]] |budget = |patron = |organized = SXSW, LLC |website = {{url|sxsw.com}} }} '''South by Southwest''' (abbreviated as '''SXSW''' and colloquially referred to as '''South By''') is an annual conglomerate of film, [[interactive media]], and [[music festival]]s and [[Convention (meeting)|conferences]] that take place in mid-March in [[Austin, Texas]], [[United States]]. It began in 1987, and has continued to grow in both scope and size every year. In 2017, the conference lasted for 10 days with SXSW interactive lasting for five days, music for seven days and film running concurrently for nine days. Comedy and gaming components to the festival are particularly fast-growing. SXSW is run by the company SXSW, LLC which organizes conferences, trade shows, festivals, and other events.{{cite web|url=http://sxswedu.com/about/history |title=Sxsw Inc |publisher=Sxswedu.com |date= |accessdate=March 25, 2014}} In addition to the three main South by Southwest festivals, the company runs other conferences: SXSW EDU, a conference on educational innovation, held in Austin,{{cite web|url=http://sxswedu.com/about |title=About SXSW EDU |publisher=Sxswedu.com |date= |accessdate=April 15, 2013}} and (beginning in 2017) the me Convention, held in [[Frankfurt]], Germany, in collaboration with [[Mercedes-Benz]].{{cite web|url=http://media.daimler.com/marsMediaSite/en/instance/ko/South-by-Southwest-SXSW-to-collaborate-with-Mercedes-Benz-at-IAA-International-Motor-Show-in-Frankfurt-Premiere-at-IAA-International-me-Convention.xhtml?oid=16074145|title=South by Southwest (SXSW) to collaborate with Mercedes-Benz at IAA International Motor Show in Frankfurt: Premiere at IAA: International me Convention|last=Schultz|first=Ina|date=March 11, 2017|website=media.daimler.com|language=en-EN|access-date=2017-08-23}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.sxsw.com/news/2017/sxsw-joins-mercedes-benz-host-future-focused-convention-frankfurt/|title=SXSW and Mercedes-Benz Announce Initial Programming for Collaborative Future-Focused Event in Europe|last=Roberts|first=Jordan|date=2017-06-14|work=SXSW|access-date=2017-08-23|language=English}} Former conferences run by the SXSW organization were SXSW Eco, an environmental conference held in Austin from 2011 to 2016;{{cite web|url=http://sxsweco.com/about |title=About SXSW Eco |publisher=Sxsweco.com |date= |accessdate=April 15, 2013}} and one in Las Vegas: [[SXSW V2V]], a conference focused on innovative [[startup company|startups]]{{cite web|url=http://www.statesman.com/news/technology/sxsw-interactive-expanding-next-year-with-las-vega/nSmFZ/ |title= SXSW Interactive expanding next year with Las Vegas startup conference|last=Gallaga|first=Omar L.|publisher=Austin American-Statesman |date=October 23, 2012 |accessdate=August 8, 2013}} which ran from 2013 to 2015. ==Divisions== [[File:Sixth Street SXSW 2013-025426539592444897.jpg|thumb|A view of [[Sixth Street (Austin, Texas)|6th Street]] in downtown Austin, Texas, during SXSW 2013]] === Music === SXSW Music is the largest [[music festival]] of its kind in the world, with more than 2,000 acts as of 2014.{{cite web|title = SXSW 2015: The festival changes, but for the better?|url = http://www.latimes.com/entertainment/music/la-et-ms-sxsw-music-wrap-20150323-story.html|website = latimes.com|accessdate = 2015-11-16}} SXSW Music offers artist-provided music and video samples of featured artists at each festival via their official YouTube channel.{{cite web |last=Birney |first=Adrienne |authorlink= |title=SXSW Technical Coordinator |work= |publisher= |date= |url=http://sxsw.com/ |doi= |accessdate=November 28, 2011}}{{cite web|url=http://sites.sxsw.com/|title=The Official SXSW site|publisher=Sites.sxsw.com|accessdate=2015-08-13}}{{dead link|date=September 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} The music event has grown from 700 registrants in 1987 to over 28,000 registrants. SXSW Film and SXSW Interactive events have grown every year, most recently bringing over 51,000 registrants to Austin every March.{{cite web |url=http://sxsw.com/about/history |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110813151035/http://sxsw.com/about/history |archivedate=2011-08-13 |title=About SXSW |accessdate=March 8, 2009}} Bands must cover their own expenses for travel and lodging at the event. All performers are offered a cash payment or a wristband package that allows access to all music events.{{cite news|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/zackomalleygreenburg/2013/03/18/why-most-acts-dont-get-paid-at-south-by-southwest/ |title=Why Most Acts Don't Get Paid At South By Southwest |publisher=Forbes |date=March 18, 2013 |accessdate=March 17, 2014}} === Film === SXSW Film Conference spans five days of conference panels and sessions, and welcomes filmmakers of all levels. Programming consists of keynote speakers, panels, workshops, mentor sessions and more, with expert filmmakers and industry leaders.{{cite web |url=http://sxsw.com/film/history |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150404164219/http://sxsw.com/film/history |archivedate=2015-04-04 |title= History |work= |publisher= SXSW.com |date= |accessdate=2015-04-04}} In 2015, the SXSW Film Conference programmed over 250 sessions with 735 speakers. Past notable speakers include [[Jon Favreau]], [[Mark Duplass]], [[Ava DuVernay]], [[Ryan Gosling]], [[Nicolas Cage]], [[Alejandro Jodorowsky]], [[Tilda Swinton]], [[Amy Schumer]], [[Sally Field]], [[Joss Whedon]], [[Christine Vachon]], [[RZA]], [[Matthew McConaughey]], [[Danny Boyle]], [[Seth MacFarlane]], [[Catherine Hardwicke]], [[Richard Linklater]], [[David Gordon Green]], [[Harmony Korine]], [[Henry Rollins]], [[Sarah Green (film producer)|Sarah Green]] and [[Robert Rodriguez]].{{cite web|url=http://www.sxsw.com/film/conference/past-speakers |title=SXSW LLC. |publisher=sxsw.com |date= |accessdate=July 14, 2015}} Although the film festival often highlights independently produced films and emerging directing talent with unique visions,{{cite web |last=Peters |first=Yves |title=''Man & Gun'' and ''Les Bleus de Ramville'' Win SXSW Film Design Awards|url=http://fontfeed.com/archives/man-film-design-awards/ |publisher=The Font Feed |accessdate=January 11, 2013 |date=March 31, 2012}} the festival has long served studios as a starting point for their comedies, using enthusiastic fans as a barometer of how they might play in wide release.{{cite news |last=Murphy |first=Mekado |title=SXSW 2015: Films That Were the Talk of the Festival |url=http://artsbeat.blogs.nytimes.com/2015/03/19/sxsw-2015-films-that-were-the-talk-of-the-festival/ |publisher=New York Times |accessdate=July 11, 2015 |date=March 19, 2015}} The SXSW Film Festival runs nine days, simultaneously with the SXSW Film Conference, and celebrates raw innovation and emerging talent both behind and in front of the camera.{{cite web|url=http://www.sxsw.com/film/about |title=SXSW LLC. |publisher=sxsw.com |date= |accessdate=July 14, 2015}} Festival programming categories include: Special Events, Headliners, Narrative Spotlight, Documentary Spotlight, Narrative Competition, Documentary Competition, Visions, Midnighters, 24 Beats Per Second, SXGlobal, Episodic, Festival Favorites and Short Film Programs. The SXSW Film Awards, which occur on the last day of the Film Conference, honor films selected by the Feature and Short Film Juries. In 2015, the SXSW Film Festival programmed 150 feature films and 106 short films, selected from 7,361 submissions.{{cite web |url=http://www.sxsw.com/sites/default/files/attachments/SXSW-FILM-FESTIVAL-ANNOUNCES-2015%20COMPLETE-CONFERENCE-LINEUP-AND-ADDITIONAL-FESTIVAL-TITLES-IMMEDIATE.pdf |title=SXSW LLC. |publisher=sxsw.com |date= |accessdate=July 14, 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150924112924/http://www.sxsw.com/sites/default/files/attachments/SXSW-FILM-FESTIVAL-ANNOUNCES-2015%20COMPLETE-CONFERENCE-LINEUP-AND-ADDITIONAL-FESTIVAL-TITLES-IMMEDIATE.pdf |archivedate=September 24, 2015 |df= }} Past notable world premieres include ''[[Furious 7]]'', ''[[Neighbors (2014 film)|Neighbors]]'', ''[[Chef (2014 film)|Chef]]'', ''[[21 Jump Street (film)|21 Jump Street]]'', ''[[The Cabin in the Woods]]'', ''[[Bridesmaids (2011 film)|Bridesmaids]]'' and ''[[Insidious (film)|Insidious]]'', and the TV series ''[[Girls (TV series)|Girls]]'', ''[[Silicon Valley (TV series)|Silicon Valley]]'' and ''[[Penny Dreadful (TV series)|Penny Dreadful]]''.{{cite web |url=http://sxsw.com/film/screenings/past-films |title=Past Films at SXSW | South by Southwest 2016 Music, Film and Interactive Festivals – Austin Texas |publisher=Sxsw.com |date= |accessdate=2015-08-13 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150609232442/http://www.sxsw.com/film/screenings/past-films |archivedate=2015-06-09 |df= }} === Interactive === SXSW Interactive is focused on emerging technology, a focus which has earned the festival a reputation as a breeding ground for new ideas and creative technologies.{{cite web|url=http://sxsw.com/interactive/about |title=Interactive News | SXSW 2013 |publisher=Sxsw.com |date= |accessdate=April 15, 2013}} The festival includes a trade show, speakers, parties, and a startup accelerator.{{cite web|url=http://sxsw.com/interactive/accelerator |title=March 8–9: SXSW Accelerator Presented by Oracle Helps Uncover Amazing New Startups | SXSW 2014 |publisher=Sxsw.com |date=November 10, 2013 |accessdate=March 25, 2014}} According to a festival organizer [[Louis Black]], SXSW Interactive "has probably been the biggest of its kind in the world" since 2007.[https://web.archive.org/web/20110311034107/http://www.dailytexanonline.com/content/sxsw-stays-course-continues-growth SXSW stays course, continues growth], Alex Geiser, ''[[The Daily Texan]]'', March 18, 2010 ==History== ===Inauguration – 1980s=== In July 1986, the organizers of the [[New York City]] music festival [[New Music Seminar]] contacted Roland Swenson, a staffer at the [[alternative weekly]] ''[[The Austin Chronicle]]'', about organizing an extension of that festival into Austin after having announced that they were going to hold a "New Music Seminar Southwest".{{cite web|author=van Arts Labor |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=iH02tbDy_6M&t=1m19s&list=UUgk1rvr62MBcRrTBgI4oEUg |title=SXSW documentary 'Outside Industry' |publisher=Youtube.com |date=February 28, 2014 |accessdate=March 25, 2014}} The plans did not materialize, so Swenson decided to instead co-organize a local music festival, with the help of two other people at the ''Chronicle'': editor and co-founder Louis Black, and publisher Nick Barbaro. Louis Meyers, a [[booking agent]] and musician, was also brought on board.[http://www.lib.utexas.edu/taro/utcah/01476/cah-01476.html A Guide to the South By Southwest, Inc., Records, 1987–1997], Briscoe Center for American History, The University of Texas at Austin Black came up with the name, as a play on the name of the [[Alfred Hitchcock]] film ''[[North by Northwest]]''. The event was first held in March 1987. The organizers considered it a regional event and expected around 150 attendees to show up, but over 700 came, and according to Black "it was national almost immediately." Meyers left Austin and the festival in the early 1990s, but Black, Barbaro and Swenson remained the festival's key organizers as of 2010. ===1990s=== Singer-songwriter [[Michelle Shocked]] was the keynote speaker at the 1992 South by Southwest. She caused controversy by delivering a speech, written by her then-husband [[Bart Bull]], criticizing white musicians for stealing music from [[African American]] artists; and then later during the same conference when she tried to kick the band [[Two Nice Girls]] off of a benefit concert, a move that some called anti-gay, due to Two Nice Girls' overtly [[lesbian]] image.[http://www.dallasobserver.com/1996-04-25/music/the-education-of-michelle-shocked/ The Education of Michelle Shocked], Robert Wilonsky, ''[[Dallas Observer]]'', April 25, 1996 In 1993, SXSW moved into the [[Austin Convention Center]], where it is still held.[http://sxsw.com/node/5521] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120322004257/http://sxsw.com/node/5521|date=March 22, 2012}} In 1994, SXSW added a component for film and other media, named the "SXSW Film and Multimedia Conference". [[Johnny Cash]] was the keynote speaker.{{cite news|last1=Cohen|first1=Jason|title=SXSW: The Ten Best Music Keynote Speakers|url=http://www.texasmonthly.com/story/sxsw-ten-best-music-keynote-speakers|accessdate=13 June 2014|work=[[Texas Monthly]]|publisher=Emmis Publishing, L.P.|date=15 March 2012}} That year, the three brothers of the band [[Hanson (band)|Hanson]] were brought to SXSW by their father in order to perform impromptu auditions for music executives, in the hopes of getting industry attention. Among the people who heard them was A&R executive [[Christopher Sabec]], who became their manager, and would soon afterward get them signed to [[Mercury Records]].{{cite web |url=http://www.oklahomatoday.com/Site/pdf/1997Hanson.pdf |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101104185941/http://www.oklahomatoday.com/Site/pdf/1997Hanson.pdf |archivedate=2010-11-04 |title= 1997 Oklahoman of the Year |work= |publisher= Oklahoma Today |date= |accessdate=4 November 2010}} In 1995, the SXSW Film and Multimedia Conference was split into two separate events, "SXSW Film" and "SXSW Multimedia". In 1999, SXSW Multimedia was renamed "SXSW Interactive". ===2000s=== Singer-songwriter [[John Mayer]]'s performance at the 2000 SXSW Music festival led to his signing soon thereafter with [[Aware Records]], his first [[record label]]. A performance by the band [[The Polyphonic Spree]] at the 2002 SXSW Music festival helped bring them to national attention before they had signed with a major label.{{cite web|url=http://www.vh1.com/news/articles/1471511/20030424/polyphonic_spree.jhtml|title=Polyphonic Spree: From Voices In A Singer's Head To Voices On The Stage - News - VH1.com|date=19 October 2011|publisher=|deadurl=bot: unknown|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111019215642/http://www.vh1.com/news/articles/1471511/20030424/polyphonic_spree.jhtml|archivedate=19 October 2011|df=}} At the 2002 SXSW Film Festival, the film ''[[Manito (film)|Manito]]'' won the jury award for narrative feature, while the documentary ''[[Spellbound (2002 film)|Spellbound]]'' won the jury award for documentary feature. British singer [[James Blunt]] was discovered by producer [[Linda Perry]] while playing a small show at the 2004 SXSW Music festival, and was signed to Perry's [[Custard Records]] soon thereafter,{{cite news|last=Miller |first=Nancy |url=http://www.ew.com/ew/article/0,,1174154,00.html |title=Five rounds with James Blunt |publisher=EW.com |date=2006-03-17 |accessdate=2015-08-13}} where he would go on to release all three of his subsequent albums. The 2005 SXSW Film is considered by some to be the origin of the [[mumblecore]] film genre. A number of films now classified as mumblecore, including ''[[The Puffy Chair]]'', ''[[Kissing on the Mouth]]'', ''[[Four Eyed Monsters]]'' and ''[[Mutual Appreciation]]'', were screened, and [[Eric Masunaga]], a musician and the [[audio engineering|sound editor]] on ''Mutual Appreciation'', is credited with coining the term "mumblecore" at a bar while at the festival.Lim, Dennis (August 19, 2007). "[https://www.nytimes.com/2007/08/19/movies/19lim.html?8dpc Mumblecore – The New Talkies: Generation DIY]". ''[[The New York Times]]''. The film ''[[Hooligans (film)|Hooligans]]'' won both the Feature Film Jury Award and the Feature Film Audience Award for narrative feature, while ''The Puffy Chair'' won the Feature Film Audience Award in the "Emerging Visions" category. The documentary film ''[[Cowboy del Amor]]'' won the SXSW Competition Award and the Audience Award. A secret concert at the 2006 SXSW Music by the band [[The Flaming Lips]] was called one of the "Top 10 Music-Festival Moments" of all time by ''[[Time (magazine)|Time]]'' magazine in 2010.[http://www.time.com/time/specials/packages/article/0,28804,1885895_1885893_1885860,00.html Top 10 Music-Festival Moments: Flaming Lips at SXSW — 2006], Dan Fletcher, ''Time'', March 18, 2010 The 2006 SXSW Interactive featured a keynote panel of Wikipedia co-founder [[Jimmy Wales]] and [[Craigslist]] founder [[Craig Newmark]].[http://www.auscillate.com/post/95 SXSW 2006 Panel: Craig Newmark & Jimmy Wales Keynote], ''Auscillate'' blog, March 13, 2006 That year, "Screenburn at SXSW", a component for [[video game]]s, was added to SXSW Interactive. The 2007 music festival took place from March 14 to 18, and more than 1,400 acts performed. Two of the top film premieres that year were ''[[Elvis and Anabelle]]'' and ''[[Skills Like This]]''. The [[social media]] platform [[Twitter]] notably gained a good deal of early traction and buzz at the 2007 SXSW Interactive,[http://www.quora.com/What-is-the-process-involved-in-launching-a-startup-at-SXSW What is the process involved in launching a startup at SXSW?], ''[[Quora]]'' though it did not launch at SXSW 2007 as is sometimes reported. The 2008 SXSW Interactive got media attention due to a keynote interview of [[Facebook]] CEO [[Mark Zuckerberg]] by technology journalist [[Sarah Lacy]] that was considered by some observers to be a "train wreck" due to an audience perception that Lacy was asking uninteresting questions, as well as mocking or terse answers in response from Zuckerberg.[http://news.cnet.com/8301-13772_3-9889528-52.html Journalist becomes the story at Mark Zuckerberg SXSWi keynote], Daniel Terdiman, ''CNET'' "Geek Gestalt" blog, March 9, 2008 In 2008, a comedy element was added to SXSW; it was held for one night. (By 2012, comedy performances occurred on all nights of the festival.){{cite web |title=Messin' with Texas: Why Doesn't SXSW Pay its Comedians? |url=http://splitsider.com/2012/01/messin-with-texas-why-doesnt-sxsw-pay-its-comedians/ |publisher=''[[Splitsider]]'' |first=Richard |last=Morgan |date=January 23, 2012}} The 2009 festival was held March 13–22. The Interactive section of SXSW in particular drew larger attendance levels; the influx strained the networks of providers such as [[AT&T]] (primarily due to heavy [[iPhone]] usage).{{cite news |url=http://blog.wired.com/business/2009/03/sxsw-atts-spott.html |title=SXSW: IPhone Influx Pushes AT&T to the Limit |work=Epicenter (blog.wired.com) |publisher=[[Condé Nast Publications|Conde Nast]] |date=March 14, 2009 |first=Michael |last=Calore}} Also new was the founding of an international organization for those not attending, dubbed NotAtSXSW. Coordinating through [[Twitter]] and other online tools, notatsxsw events were held in London, New York, Wisconsin, Portland, Oregon and Miami.{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/music/musicblog/2009/mar/18/notatsxsw-festival-twitter |title= Can't make it to SXSW this year? Go to #notatsxsw instead |date=March 18, 2009 |work=[[The Guardian]] | location=London | accessdate=May 23, 2010 | first=Ruth | last=Jamieson}} [[Image:Foursquare-logo.png|thumb|The mobile app, Foursquare, was launched at SXSW 2009.]] The 2009 SXSW Interactive saw the launch of the [[Foursquare (social network)|Foursquare]] application, which was called "the breakout [[mobile app]]" of the event by the ''[[Mashable]]'' blog.{{cite web|last=Van |first=Jennifer |url=http://mashable.com/2009/03/16/foursquare/ |title=Foursquare is the Breakout Mobile App at SXSW |publisher=Mashable.com |date=2009-03-16 |accessdate=2015-08-13}} The 2009 SXSW Film screened 250 films, including 54 world premieres. The event was notable for having the United States premiere of the film ''[[The Hurt Locker]]'', which went on to win the [[Academy Award for Best Picture]] in 2010. The winners of the feature jury awards were, for documentary feature, ''[[45365]]'', and for narrative feature, ''[[Made in China (2009 film)|Made in China]]''.{{cite news|author=|url=http://www.indiewire.com/article/made_in_china_and_45365_take_top_sxsw_jury_prizes/ |title="Made in China" and "45365" Take Top SXSW Jury Prizes |publisher=Indiewire |date=March 18, 2009 |accessdate=February 22, 2011}} ===2010=== The 2010 music festival, which took place March 12–21, was dedicated to [[Alex Chilton]], who died shortly before he was to perform with [[Big Star]].{{cite web|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/news/big-star-singer-and-cult-icon-alex-chilton-dead-at-59-20100317|title=Big Star Singer and Cult Icon Alex Chilton Dead at 59|date=March 17, 2010|accessdate=Sep 24, 2014}} A tribute concert was performed in his honor on March 20, 2010.{{cite web|url=http://sxsw.tewspaper.com/at-the-big-star-tribute-to-alex-chilton-sxsw-32010|title=SXSW Tribute Concert for Alex Chilton|date=March 20, 2010|accessdate=March 24, 2010|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110716212414/http://sxsw.tewspaper.com/at-the-big-star-tribute-to-alex-chilton-sxsw-32010|archivedate=July 16, 2011|df=}} At the 2010 festival, nearly 2,000 bands were officially scheduled to perform,{{cite web|url=http://www.nbcnewyork.com/entertainment/music/SXSW-2010-Draws-to-a-Close-88819997.html|title=SXSW 2010 Draws to a Close|publisher=nbcnewyork.com|date=March 22, 2010 |accessdate=April 8, 2010}} and festival reps estimated that over 13,000 industry representatives attended.{{cite web|url=http://www.dailyfinance.com/story/media/scenes-from-the-geekfest-at-sxsw-interactive/19398388|title=Scenes From the Geekfest at SXSW|publisher=DailyFinance.com |date=March 14, 2010 |accessdate=April 8, 2010}} Though traditionally the Austin Music Awards kick off the festival, that year organizers slated it as the closing act. Local musician [[Bob Schneider]] earned 6 awards, including Song of the Year, Singer of the Year, and Band of the Year (with [[Lonelyland]].) The 2010 festival was also notable for appearances by the surviving members of the band [[Moby Grape]].Raul Hernandez, [http://www.austinchronicle.com/gyrobase/Issue/review?oid=oid%3A985722 Live Shots: SXSW Music 2010], [[Austin Chronicle]], March 26, 2010. At the 2010 Film festival, [[Magnolia Pictures]] bought the film rights to the science-fiction film ''[[Monsters (2010 film)|Monsters]]'' on the night it screened, in what was the first-ever "overnight acquisition" at SXSW. Journalist Meredith Melnick of ''[[Time (magazine)|Time]]'' magazine called this purchase a turning point for SXSW, leading to a greater interest among film studio executives in attending the festival in person.[http://www.time.com/time/arts/article/0,8599,2062263,00.html Art of the Film Deal: Is South by Southwest Becoming the New Sundance?], Meredith Melnick, ''Time'', April 1, 2011 That year also saw the premiere of the indie favorite ''[[Tiny Furniture]]'', which won the award for Best Narrative Feature. The 2010 Interactive festival had an estimated 12–13,000 paying attendees, which represented a 40% jump over the previous year.[http://www.austin360.com/blogs/content/shared-gen/blogs/austin/digitalsavant/entries/2010/03/17/confirmed_sxsw.html Confirmed: SXSW Interactive paid registration surpasses Music], Omar L. Gallaga, ''Austin360.com'', March 17, 2010 This was the first year in which the interactive festival's attendance surpassed the music festival's. The keynote presentation was an interview of then-Twitter CEO [[Evan Williams (Internet entrepreneur)|Evan Williams]] by Umair Haque, an interview that many in the audience found disappointingly superficial.[http://www.statesman.com/business/sxsw-organizers-concede-keynote-flubs-with-twitter-q-374628.html SXSW organizers concede keynote flubs with Twitter Q&A], Omar L. Gallaga, ''Austin American-Statesman'', March 16, 2010 Also during the interactive festival, the first-ever (and so far only) "Hive Awards For the Unsung Heroes of the Internet" were held. ===2011=== [[File:Conan O'Brien - SXSW - Mar 2011.jpg|thumb|upright|[[Conan O'Brien]] promoting ''[[Conan O'Brien Can't Stop]]'' at SXSW 2011]] The 2011 SXSW festival ran from March 11 to 20. The keynote presenter for SXSW Interactive was [[Seth Priebatsch]], founder and CEO of the mobile-gaming platform [[SCVNGR]].{{cite web|url=http://www.cnet.com/8301-14013_1-20042504-284.html|title=SCVNGR at SXSW--high-flying, or head in the clouds?|date=March 12, 2011|accessdate=March 12, 2011}} The 2011 Interactive festival was by far the largest it had ever been, with an estimated 20,000 attendees.[http://www.dailyfinance.com/story/where-the-geeks-are-dispatches-from-the-largest-sxsw-interactiv/19880235/ Where the Geeks Are: Dispatches From the Largest SXSW Interactive Ever], L. A. Lorek, ''Daily Finance'', March 15, 2011 Also in attendance at SXSW was boxing legend [[Mike Tyson]], promoting his new iPhone game with [[RockLive]] at the Screenburn Arcade.{{cite web|last=McCarthy |first=Caroline |url=http://www.cnet.com/8301-14013_1-20042682-284.html |title=Mike Tyson wants to be an iPhone knockout | SXSW – CNET Blogs |publisher=Cnet.com |date=March 13, 2011 |accessdate=April 15, 2013}} At least two films screened at the SXSW Film festival gained distribution deals: the documentary ''[[Undefeated (2011 film)|Undefeated]]'' (which went on to win the [[Academy Award for Best Documentary Feature]]) and the thriller ''[[The Divide (2011 film)|The Divide]]''. As a result, film critic Christopher Kelly wrote that in 2011, SXSW Film went from being "a well-regarded but fundamentally regional event" to having "joined the big leagues of film festivals around the world."[http://www.dfw.com/2011/03/17/424689/commentary-south-by-southwest.html Commentary: South by Southwest is in danger of losing its indie film cred] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120315165235/http://www.dfw.com/2011/03/17/424689/commentary-south-by-southwest.html |date=2012-03-15 }}, Christopher Kelly, DFW.com, March 17, 2011 That festival was also notable for having the premiere of the film ''[[Bridesmaids (2011 film)|Bridesmaids]]''.[http://latimesblogs.latimes.com/movies/2012/03/sxsw-2012-21-jump-street-cabin-in-the-woods-aspire-to-bridesmaids-style-success-.html SXSW: '21 Jump St.,' 'Cabin in the Woods' eye 'Bridesmaids' bouquet], Mark Olsen, ''24 Frames'' (''Los Angeles Times'' blog), March 8, 2012 The March 15th screening of the [[Foo Fighters]] documentary ''[[Back and Forth (documentary)|Back and Forth]]'' was followed by a surprise live performance by the band itself, with a setlist that included the entirety of the then-upcoming album ''[[Wasting Light]]''.{{cite web|url=http://blog.vh1.com/2011-03-16/foo-fighters-documentary-premiere-followed-by-surprise-show/|title=Foo Fighters Documentary Premiere Followed By Surprise Show|work=VH1 Blog Reality TV News and Gossip|access-date=2011-12-04|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120208075146/http://blog.vh1.com/2011-03-16/foo-fighters-documentary-premiere-followed-by-surprise-show|archive-date=2012-02-08|dead-url=yes|df=}} ===2012=== SXSW 2012 ran from March 9 to 18. The standout technology of the 2012 SXSW Interactive was generally stated to be "[[social discovery platform|social discovery]]" mobile apps, which let users locate other nearby users. Social discovery apps that had a presence at SXSW included [[Highlight (application)|Highlight]], Glancee, Sonar and Kismet.[http://news.cnet.com/8301-1035_3-57393877-94/hottest-new-apps-out-of-sxsw-2012/ Hottest new apps out of SXSW 2012], Jaymar Cabebe and Jason Parker, ''CNET'', March 12, 2012[http://content.usatoday.com/communities/livefrom/post/2012/03/sxsw-2012-the-highlight-of-the-festival/1#.T8SqJUWmgrU SXSW 2012: The 'Highlight' of the festival], Jon Swartz, ''USA Today'', March 13, 2012 SXSW Film saw the premiere of two major Hollywood films: ''[[The Cabin in the Woods]]''[http://www.statesman.com/news/texas/in-shadows-of-hype-dialogue-of-too-much-2235412.html In shadows of hype, dialogue of 'too much' at SXSW], Jake Coyle, ''The Associated Press" March 13, 2012 {{dead link|date=June 2016|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}} and ''[[21 Jump Street (film)|21 Jump Street]]''. Two films obtained distribution deals: ''[[Girls Against Boys (film)|Girls Against Boys]]'' and ''[[The Tall Man (2012 film)|The Tall Man]]''.[http://thefilmstage.com/news/sxsw-features-girls-against-boys-and-the-tall-man-picked-up-for-distribution-barrymore-to-finally-see-light-of-day/ SXSW Features ‘Girls Against Boys’ and ‘The Tall Man’ Picked Up For Distribution; ‘Barrymore’ To Finally See Light Of Day], Amanda Waltz, ''The Film Stage'', March 13, 2012 Another film, ''[[Gimme the Loot (film)|Gimme the Loot]]'', which won the SXSW Narrative Feature Grand Jury Prize, got a distribution deal a week after the festival.[http://insidemovies.ew.com/2012/03/19/sxsw-gimme-the-loot-adam-leon-sundance-select/ SXSW: 'Gimme the Loot' director Adam Leon on winning big, landing distribution deal], Karen Valby, ''Entertainment Weekly: Inside Movies'', March 19, 2012 ''[[Bay of All Saints (film)|Bay of All Saints]]'' received the Audience Award for Best Feature Documentary.{{cite news|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/review/bay-all-saints-sxsw-film-review-301724|title=Bay of All Saints: SXSW Review|author=John DeFore|work=The Hollywood Reporter|date=March 19, 2012}} 2012 was also the first year the music portion was expanded to Tuesday. The musical festival included rappers such as [[Talib Kweli]] and [[Lil' Wayne]], along with surprise appearances by [[Big Sean]] and [[Kanye West]]; indie bands that appeared included [[MENEW]] and [[The Shins]]. [[Bruce Springsteen]] was the keynote speaker for the music festival.{{cite web|url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/events/sxsw/501218/bruce-springsteens-sxsw-keynote-stay-hard-stay-hungry |title=Bruce Springsteen's SXSW Keynote: 'Stay Hard, Stay Hungry' |publisher=Billboard |date=March 15, 2012 |accessdate=April 15, 2013}} ===2013=== SXSW 2013 ran from March 8 to 17. The big-budget films ''[[The Incredible Burt Wonderstone]]'' and ''[[Evil Dead (2013 film)|Evil Dead]]'' premiered at the 2013 SXSW Film, and ''[[Spring Breakers]]'' had its U.S. premiere.[http://blogs.indiewire.com/theplaylist/sxsw-2013-brings-burt-wonderstone-spring-breakers-evil-dead-drinking-buddies-more-to-austin-20130115 SXSW 2013 Brings 'Burt Wonderstone,' Spring Breakers,' 'Evil Dead,' 'Drinking Buddies' & More To Austin], Kevin Jagernauth, ''Indiewire'', January 15, 2013 The film ''[[Short Term 12]]'' won the grand jury award for Best Narrative Feature. The films ''[[Cheap Thrills (film)|Cheap Thrills]]'' and ''[[Haunter (film)|Haunter]]'' received distribution deals,{{cite news |title=SXSW 2013: 'Short Term 12' wins feature prize |url=http://www.latimes.com/entertainment/envelope/moviesnow/la-et-mn-sxsw-wrapup-20130313,0,1786750.story |publisher=Los Angeles Times |date=March 12, 2013 |first=Mark |last=Olsen}} and ''[[Drinking Buddies]]'' obtained a distribution deal several days later.{{cite web |title=Magnolia Acquires SXSW Pic ‘Drinking Buddies’ |url=http://www.deadline.com/2013/03/drinking-buddies-magnolia-pictures-acquired-sxsw-joe-swanberg/ |date=March 19, 2013 |first=Jen |last=Yamato |publisher=Deadline}} The 2013 SXSW Interactive saw another huge jump in registration, now with 30,621 paying attendees.Nicole Villalpando, [http://www.statesman.com/news/events/biggest-interactive-yet-as-sxsw-begins-music-hands/nWqPc/ "Biggest Interactive yet as SXSW begins Music, hands out Film Awards"], ''Austin American Statesman'', March 12, 2013. Retrieved on March 13, 2013 This was over three times the number that had attended in 2008 (9,000), just five years previously.[http://www.prnewswire.com/news-releases/2008-sxsw-interactive-festival-wraps-up-strong-year-57369557.html 2008 SXSW Interactive Festival Wraps Up Strong Year], ''PRNewswire'', March 31, 2008 The keynote talk for the 2013 SXSW Interactive was given by [[SpaceX]] CEO [[Elon Musk]].[https://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/innovations/post/sxsw-2013-this-revolution-is-brought-to-you-by/2013/03/11/b47dfa10-8a95-11e2-8d72-dc76641cb8d4_blog.html SXSW 2013: This revolution is brought to you by...], Hamdan Azhar, ''Washington Post'' ideas@innovations blog, March 11, 2013 The "Screenburn" and "Arcade" components were renamed to "SXSW Gaming" and "SXSW Gaming Expo", respectively.[http://iqu.com/blog/south-by-southwest-interactive-video-games SXSW Interactive: A Growing Outlet For Video Games], Matt Clark, ''iQU', March 14, 2012 {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130524055251/http://iqu.com/blog/south-by-southwest-interactive-video-games |date=May 24, 2013 }} The Interactive conference was noted for its increased corporate presence, featuring major participation by [[Samsung]], [[3M]], [[Target Corporation|Target]], [[American Airlines]], [[Adobe Systems]] and [[AT&T]], among others.[https://www.reuters.com/article/2013/03/11/us-sxsw-startups-idUSBRE92A10I20130311 At South by Southwest, fewer startups, more marketers and media], Gerry Shih, Reuters, March 11, 2013 According to [[CNN]], [[CBS]] and [[CNET]] called [[Grumpy Cat]] the undisputed "biggest star" of SXSW Interactive over Musk, [[Al Gore]] and [[Neil Gaiman]].{{cite news|url=http://www.cnn.com/2013/03/10/tech/web/grumpy-cat-sxsw/index.html |title=The unlikely star of SXSW: Grumpy Cat |publisher=CNN.com |date=November 14, 2011 |accessdate=March 11, 2013}}{{cite news|author=March 11, 2013, 5:54 PM |url=http://www.cbsnews.com/8301-205_162-57573676/as-sxsw-interactive-winds-down-grumpy-cat-is-clear-winner/ |title=As SXSW Interactive winds down, Grumpy cat is clear winner |publisher=CBS News |date= |accessdate=March 3, 2013}}{{cite web|last=Terdiman |first=Daniel |url=http://news.cnet.com/8301-14013_3-57573517/if-grumpy-cat-is-the-biggest-news-of-all-is-sxsw-in-trouble/ |title=If Grumpy Cat is the biggest news of all, is SXSW in trouble? | SXSW – CNET News |publisher=News.cnet.com |date=January 23, 2013 |accessdate=March 13, 2013}} === 2014 === SXSW 2014 ran from March 7 to 16. SXSW Film had premieres of the big-budget films ''[[Neighbors (2014 film)|Neighbors]]'', ''[[Veronica Mars (film)|Veronica Mars]]'' and ''[[Chef (2014 film)|Chef]]'', and ''[[Cesar Chavez (film)|Cesar Chavez]]'' had its North American premiere.{{cite news |title=South by Southwest Adds a TV Section |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2014/01/31/business/media/south-by-southwest-festival-adds-a-tv-section.html |publisher=''[[The New York Times]]'' |first=Michael |last=Cieply |date=January 30, 2014}}{{cite news |title=SXSW 2014: Five movie stories, including 'Chef' and 'Veronica Mars' |url=http://www.latimes.com/entertainment/movies/moviesnow/la-et-mn-sxsw-film-festival-reviews-chef-neighbors-veronica-mar-20140310,0,5139256.story |publisher=''[[Los Angeles Times]]'' |first=Oliver |last=Gettell |date=March 10, 2014}} A clip for the big-budget film ''[[Godzilla (2014 film)|Godzilla]]'' was also screened. The films ''[[Space Station 76]]''{{cite web|url=http://www.socialitelife.com/matt-bomers-space-station-76-lands-a-distribution-deal-at-sxsw-03-2014|title=Matt Bomer’s ‘Space Station 76′ Lands A Distribution Deal At SXSW – Socialite Life Socialite Life|work=Socialite Life|access-date=2015-03-16|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150402103719/http://www.socialitelife.com/matt-bomers-space-station-76-lands-a-distribution-deal-at-sxsw-03-2014|archive-date=2015-04-02|dead-url=yes|df=}} and ''[[Exists (film)|Exists]]'' got distribution deals at the festival, while ''[[Fort Tilden (film)|Fort Tilden]]'' (which won the Narrative Feature Grand Jury Prize) and ''[[Open Windows (film)|Open Windows]]'' got distribution deals shortly afterward.{{cite web |title=Elijah Wood-Sasha Grey's South by Southwest Thriller Gets U.S. Distribution |url=http://bostonherald.com/entertainment/movies/movie_news/2014/04/elijah_wood_sasha_greys_south_by_southwest_thriller_gets_us | publisher=''Boston Herald'' |date=April 1, 2014 |first=Dave |last=McNary}}{{cite news| url=https://variety.com/2015/film/news/fort-tilden-distribution-sxsw-orion-1201455504/ | work=Variety | first=Dave | last=McNary | title=SXSW 2014 Winner 'Fort Tilden' Gets U.S. Distribution From Orion | date=March 18, 2015}} A new section, "Episodic" (on television programming) was introduced to SXSW Film. Television series that previewed at the festival include ''[[Silicon Valley (TV series)|Silicon Valley]]'' and ''[[From Dusk till Dawn: The Series]]''. The talk show ''[[Jimmy Kimmel Live!]]'' was taped for a week at the festival; it joined the talk show ''[[Watch What Happens: Live]]'', which began taping at SXSW in 2013.{{cite web |title=Move over, Jimmy Kimmel: SXSW welcomes back Bravo's Andy Cohen — and his show |url=http://austin.culturemap.com/news/entertainment/01-20-14-hey-jimmy-kimmel-bravo-tv-host-andy-cohen-sxsw/ |publisher=CultureMap Austin |first=John |last=Egan |date=January 21, 2014}} SXSW Interactive featured a keynote speech by [[NSA]] leaker [[Edward Snowden]], via streaming video, about privacy rights. The festival also featured a talk from another famous leaker, [[Julian Assange]], also speaking remotely.{{cite web |url=http://articles.philly.com/2014-03-12/news/48122662_1_edward-snowden-nsa-leaker-snowden-southwest-interactive |newspaper=[[Philadelphia Inquirer]] |first=Dan |last=DeLuca |date=March 12, 2014 |title=NSA leaker Snowden is the rock star of SXSW Interactive}} Besides privacy issues, another major focus of the Interactive festival was [[wearable technology]], including devices for [[augmented reality]], [[activity tracker|activity tracking]], identity authentication, charging cell phones and others.{{cite news |title=5 things we learned at SXSW Interactive|url=http://www.cnn.com/2014/03/13/tech/web/sxsw-wrapup/ |publisher=CNN |authors=Doug Gross and Brandon Griggs |date=March 13, 2014}} ''[[Computerworld]]'' magazine called the [[Oculus Rift]], a [[virtual reality]] gaming headset, the "sleeper hit" of the festival, although it was displayed not at the Interactive but at the Film portion, as part of a ''[[Game of Thrones]]'' exhibit.{{cite web |title=Oculus Rift is the sleeper hit of SXSW |url=http://blogs.computerworld.com/computer-peripherals/23634/oculus-rift-sleeper-hit-sxsw-itbwgk |magazine=Computerworld |first=Richi |last=Jennings |date=March 10, 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140316165841/http://blogs.computerworld.com/computer-peripherals/23634/oculus-rift-sleeper-hit-sxsw-itbwgk |archivedate=March 16, 2014 |df= }} The SXSW Gaming section introduced its [[SXSW Gaming Awards]] to recognize achievement in video and other types of gaming, which has continued through future SXSW festivals. The keynote presenter and headline act this year for Stubb's was [[Lady Gaga]].{{cite web |url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/news/5930106/lady-gaga-to-headline-stubbs-at-sxsw |publisher=''[[Billboard.com]]'' |first=Andrew |last=Hampp |date=March 11, 2014 |title=Lady Gaga to Headline Stubb's at SXSW}}{{cite web |title=Lady Gaga to Present Keynote Address at SXSW |url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/news/5930300/lady-gaga-to-present-keynote-address-at-sxsw |publisher=''[[Billboard.com]]'' |first=Rutherford |last=Halperin |date=March 11, 2014}} To promote her upcoming album, ''[[Food (Kelis album)|Food]]'', [[Kelis]] cooked and served barbecue-style food from a food truck to festival attendees.{{cite web |url=https://www.theguardian.com/culture/video/2014/mar/14/sxsw-2014-kelis-food-van-austin-texas-video |title=SXSW 2014: Kelis takes her food van to the streets of Austin, Texas – video |work=The Guardian |date=March 14, 2014 |accessdate=March 14, 2014}}{{cite web |url=http://www.rap-up.com/2014/03/14/kelis-serves-up-jerk-ribs-at-sxsw-food-truck/ |title=Kelis Serves Up Jerk Ribs at SXSW Food Truck |work=[[Rap-Up]] |date=March 14, 2014 |accessdate=March 14, 2014}} On March 13, 2014, a drunk driver, Rashad Charjuan Owens, drove his car into a crowd of festival attendees while trying to evade a traffic stop.{{cite news |title=Man who drove car into SXSW festival was wannabe rapper with six kids |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/morning-mix/wp/2014/03/14/man-who-drove-car-into-swsx-festival-was-wannabe-rapper-with-six-kids/?tid=pm_national_pop |newspaper=Washington Post |first=Lindsey |last=Bever |date=March 14, 2014}} Two people were killed immediately, another two died later from their injuries and another 21 were injured but survived.{{cite news |title=4th Person Dies After SXSW Car Crash |url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2014/03/27/sxsw-crash-death_n_5044750.html |publisher=Huffington Post|date=March 27, 2014 |accessdate=March 29, 2014}} Owens was convicted of [[capital murder]] charges after a November 2015 trial in which eyewitnesses testified that about "a chaotic and harrowing scene" on the night, as hundreds of people ran and screamed as the car sped through crowds of people.Philip Jankowski & Jazmine Ulloa, [http://www.statesman.com/news/news/crime-law/three-new-pieces-of-evidence-in-the-rashad-owens-c/npHXR/ Rashad Owens guilty of capital murder in deadly SXSW crash], ''Austin American-Statesman'' (November 6, 2016).Philip Jankowski & Jazmine Ulloa, [http://www.statesman.com/news/news/crime-law/follow-the-capital-murder-trial-of-sxsw-crash-susp/npDh4/ Sixteen people, most eyewitnesses, testify in Rashad Owens trial], ''Austin American-Statesman'' (November 2, 2016). Owens was given an automatic sentence of [[life without parole|life imprisonment without the possibility of parole]].Ralph Ellis, [http://www.cnn.com/2015/11/06/us/texas-sxsw-crash/ Man who plowed car into SXSW festival crowd given life sentence], CNN (November 6, 2015). On March 15, 2014, rapper [[Tyler, The Creator]] was arrested on [[misdemeanor]] charges of "[[inciting to riot]]" after yelling to fans to push their way past security guards at a sold-out show the previous day.{{cite news |title=Rapper Tyler, The Creator arrested at South By Southwest|url=http://www.foxnews.com/entertainment/2014/03/16/rapper-tyler-creator-arrested-at-south-by-southwest/ |agency=Associated Press |date=March 16, 2014}} In February 2016, the riot charges were dropped against Tyler, The Creator pursuant to a [[plea agreement]] with prosecutors (under which the rapper pleaded guilty to the lesser offense of [[disorderly conduct]] and paid a $100 fine, with the case to be dismissed if he stays out of trouble for three months).Jazmine Ulloa, [http://www.mystatesman.com/news/news/crime-law/prosecutors-drop-riot-charge-against-rapper-tyler-/nqRYL/ As rapper's riot charge is dropped, legal experts question arrest], ''Austin American-Statesman'' (February 17, 2016). ===2015=== SXSW 2015 took place from March 13 to 22. SXSW Film screened 145 feature films, an all-time high for the festival.{{cite news|title=SXSW 2015 film lineup adds mainstream appeal|url=https://www.theguardian.com/film/2015/feb/03/sxsw-2015-film-lineup-mainstream-appeal|accessdate=February 6, 2015|date=February 3, 2015}} The big-budget films ''[[Furious 7]]'' (which was a last-minute addition to the lineup),{{cite news|author=Ramin Setoodeh |url=https://variety.com/2015/film/news/furious-7-premieres-at-sxsw-to-cheers-for-paul-walker-1201453405/ |title=‘Furious 7’ Premieres at SXSW to Cheers for Paul Walker |publisher=Variety |date=2015-03-16 |accessdate=2015-08-13}} ''[[Get Hard]]'', ''[[Spy (2015 film)|Spy]]'', a rough cut of ''[[Trainwreck (film)|Trainwreck]]'', ''[[Moonwalkers (film)|Moonwalkers]]'' and ''[[The Final Girls]]''{{cite web|url=http://consequenceofsound.net/2015/03/10-most-anticipated-films-at-sxsw-2015/full-post/|title=10 Most Anticipated Films at SXSW 2015|work=Consequence of Sound|date=March 9, 2015}} had their world premieres, as did the documentaries ''[[Danny Says (film)|Danny Says]]'',{{cite web|url=http://schedule.sxsw.com/2015/events/event_FS18314|title=Danny Says - SXSW 2015 Event Schedule|website=SXSW Schedule 2015}} ''Steve Jobs: The Man in the Machine'' and ''[[Brand: A Second Coming]]''.{{cite news |title=SXSW Premieres Include Judd Apatow's 'Trainwreck,' Melissa McCarthy in 'Spy' |url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/sxsw-premieres-include-judd-apatows-769769 |work=The Hollywood Reporter |first=Seth |last=Abramovitch |date=February 3, 2015}} ''[[Ex Machina (film)|Ex Machina]]'' had its North American premiere. ''[[6 Years]]'', ''Manson Family Vacation'' and ''Steve Jobs: The Man in the Machine'' all got distribution deals at the festival.{{cite news |title=SXSW 2015: Films That Were the Talk of the Festival |url=http://artsbeat.blogs.nytimes.com/2015/03/19/sxsw-2015-films-that-were-the-talk-of-the-festival/ |work=The New York Times |first=Mekado |last=Murphy |date=March 19, 2015}} The 2015 festival hosted the swearing-in ceremony of [[Michelle K. Lee]] as the new head of the [[United States Patent and Trademark Office]] (USPTO). [[Secretary of Commerce]] [[Penny Pritzker]] administered the oath of office to Lee at the festival on Friday, March 13.{{cite news |last1=Schwartz |first1=Eric Hal |title=New Patent Office Director Sworn In by Commerce Secretary at SXSW |url=http://dcinno.streetwise.co/2015/03/13/new-us-patent-chief-sworn-in-at-sxsw/ |accessdate=March 16, 2015 |work=DCInno |publisher=Streetwise Media |date=March 13, 2015}} Various sources called [[Meerkat (app)|Meerkat]], an iOS app that had launched two weeks earlier that lets users livestream video via Twitter, the breakout technology of SXSW Interactive.{{cite news |title=Flying cars, tracking chips: The near future, from SXSW |url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/tech/2015/03/18/sxsw-flying-cars-tracking-chips-wearables-meerkat/24926781/ |work=USA Today |first=Jefferson |last=Graham |date=March 18, 2015}}{{cite web |title=SXSW 2015: 5 Standout Moments in Technology (film)|Everybody Wants Some!!]]'', ''[[Keanu (film)|Keanu]]'', ''[[Sausage Party]]'', ''[[Pee-wee's Big Holiday]]'' and ''[[Don't Think Twice (film)|Don't Think Twice]]''.{{cite web |title=The 16 Buzziest Movies at SXSW Film Festival |url=https://variety.com/2016/film/news/sxsw-buzziest-movies-2016-festival-1201728130/ |publisher=Variety |authors=Ramin Setoodeh, Justin Chang, Joe Leydon, Andrew Barker |date=March 11, 2016}} On the night of March 20, gunshots rang out on 6th Street causing mass hysteria and panic. No injuries were reported and a man from Memphis was arrested with discharging a firearm and [[Breach of the peace|disturbing the peace]]. ===2017=== Films that premiered at SXSW Film include ''[[Song to Song]]'', ''[[Baby Driver (film)|Baby Driver]]'', ''[[Atomic Blonde]]'', ''[[Gemini (2017 film)|Gemini]]'',{{cite web |title=SXSW: Ryan Gosling, Charlize Theron Take Austin for 'Song to Song,' 'Atomic Blonde' Premieres |url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/gallery/sxsw-2017-movie-tv-premieres-gallery-song-song-baby-driver-atomic-blonde-american-gods-985632/1-song-to-song |publisher=''Hollywood Reporter'' |date=March 14, 2017}} ''[[The Ballad of Lefty Brown]]''. ''[[Spettacolo]]'' and ''[[The Disaster Artist (film)|The Disaster Artist]]''.{{cite web |title=James Franco’s ‘The Disaster Artist’ to Premiere at SXSW |url=https://variety.com/2017/film/festivals/james-franco-the-disaster-artist-premiering-at-sxsw-1201979745/ |first=Dave |last=McNary |publisher=''Variety'' |date=February 7, 2017}} Television shows that were previewed include ''[[The Son (TV series)|The Son]]'', ''[[Dear White People (TV series)|Dear White People]]'' and ''[[American Gods (TV series)|American Gods]]''. [[Nile Rodgers]] gave the keynote address for the music portion of the festival,{{Cite news|url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/events/sxsw/7727781/sxsw-nile-rodgers-keynote-address|title=Nile Rodgers Talks Making Hits & Not Being a Music Snob During SXSW Keynote Address|work=Billboard|access-date=2017-07-22}} while filmmakers [[Gareth Edwards (director)|Gareth Edwards]]{{Cite news|url=https://variety.com/2017/film/news/gareth-edwards-rogue-one-sxsw-1202007727/|title=SXSW: Gareth Edwards Explains How a Starbucks Cup Influenced ‘Rogue One’|last=Valentini|first=Valentina I.|date=2017-03-13|work=Variety|access-date=2017-07-22|language=English}} and [[Lee Daniels]]{{Cite news|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/sxsw-lee-daniels-explains-why-trump-will-be-good-hollywood-details-childhood-ghetto-985428|title=SXSW: Lee Daniels Explains Why Trump Will Be Good for Hollywood, Details Childhood in "the Ghetto"|work=The Hollywood Reporter|access-date=2017-07-22|language=en}} gave the keynote presentations for the film portion. Major companies and brands which exhibited at SXSW (many with standalone "brand activation" pavilions) included [[IBM]], [[Intel]], [[Panasonic]], [[Nintendo]], [[General Electric|GE]], [[Armani|Giorgio Armani]], [[Mazda]] and [[National Geographic Society|National Geographic]]. Major performers during the music component of the festival included [[Garth Brooks]], [[Lana Del Rey]], [[Lil Yachty]], [[The Roots]], [[The Avett Brothers]], [[Willie Nelson]], [[Solange Knowles]], [[Rae Sremmurd]], [[Migos]], and [[The Chainsmokers]] among others. En route to SXSW 2017, [[Italy|Italian]] [[post-punk]] band Soviet Soviet, traveling on the [[Visa Waiver Program]], was denied entry to the United States, detained overnight and [[deportation|deported]] after an [[U.S. Customs and Border Protection|immigration officer]] at [[Seattle–Tacoma International Airport]] claimed they were planning on conducting a paid performance, which would have required a work visa. The band presented a letter from their American [[record label]] stating that both their performances at [[KEXP-FM|KEXP]] (which was what had brought the band to Seattle) and at SXSW were for promotional purposes only, but this failed to convince officials at the airport.{{cite web|last1=Tsioulcas|first1=Anastasia|title=Italian Band Soviet Soviet Denied Entry To The U.S., Jailed And Then Deported|url=https://www.npr.org/sections/therecord/2017/03/10/519707931/italian-band-soviet-soviet-denied-entry-to-the-u-s-jailed-and-then-deported|website=NPR|publisher=NPR|accessdate=13 March 2017}} There was also a "Contrabanned" showcase on March 17, featuring various artists and musicians (residents of the U.S. and Canada) who are natives of, or have family connections to, countries affected by the [[Executive Order 13769|2017 U.S. travel ban]] on citizens from parts of the Islamic world.{{Cite news|url=http://www.chicagotribune.com/entertainment/music/ct-sxsw-contrabanned-showcase-20170318-column.html|title=SXSW: Artists representing Muslim-majority countries band together|last=Kot|first=Greg|work=chicagotribune.com|access-date=2017-08-22|language=English}}{{cite web|url=https://www.npr.org/2017/03/19/520752751/faarrow-joins-south-by-southwest-bands-in-drawing-attention-to-travel-ban|title=FAARROW Joins SXSW Bands In Drawing Attention To Travel Ban|website=NPR.org|access-date=2017-08-22}} [[Uber]] and [[Lyft]] pulled out of Austin in May 2016 as a result of a city ordinance mandating fingerprint-based background checks for drivers of any [[transportation network company]].{{cite news | url=https://www.bizjournals.com/austin/news/2016/05/07/uber-lyft-defeated-in-prop-1-referendum.html | title=Uber, Lyft defeated in Prop. 1 referendum | last=Theis | first=Michael | work=[[American City Business Journals]] | date=May 7, 2016}} However, other services such as (locally based) RideAustin, [[Fasten (company)|Fasten]] and Fare, were available, although in high demand. Uber and Lyft resumed service in Austin in May 2017.{{cite news | url=https://www.economist.com/blogs/gulliver/2017/05/not-missed | title=An inglorious return to Austin for Uber and Lyft | work=[[The Economist]] | date=May 26, 2017}} ===2018=== [[File:(L to R) IGN's Laura Prudom, Dan Jurgens, Jim Lee, Frank Miller, Brian Michael Bendis at SXSW 2018.jpg|alt=The panel seated in director's chairs|thumb|[[IGN]]'s Laura Prudom (far left) hosts a panel at 2018's South by Southwest convention discussing Superman's eightieth anniversary and the release of [[Action Comics 1000|''Action Comics'' #1000]], with (left to right): [[Dan Jurgens]], [[Jim Lee]], [[Frank Miller (comics)|Frank Miller]], and [[Brian Michael Bendis]]. Miller has an unrelated Superman project scheduled for later in the year.]] SXSW 2018 ran from March 9 to 18. Some attendees noted fewer "big name" musical acts and corporate pavilions at the festival, and fewer crowds, as compared to previous years. Finalists of the 2018 SXSW Accelerator Pitch Event included Cambridge Cancer Genomics and Bluefield Technologies.{{cite web|url=https://www.sxsw.com/interactive/2018/50-startup-finalists-announced-for-2018-sxsw-accelerator-pitch-event/|title=SXSW 2018|date=January 16, 2018|website=www.sxsw.com|access-date=2018-01-16}} Two winners of the event were Austin-based: GrubTubs (in the Hyper-Connected Communities category) and ICON 3D (in the Social and Culture category).{{Cite news|url=https://www.512tech.com/technology/two-austin-startups-win-big-sxsw-accelerator-pitch-event/OBntFCMxvqyf4wwYgmqegM/|title=Two Austin startups win big at SXSW Accelerator pitch event|last=|first=|date=|work=512 tech (Austin American-Statesman)|access-date=2018-03-18}} Guest speakers included U.S. Senator [[Bernie Sanders]] (I-Vermont); entrepreneur [[Elon Musk]]; actor and former Governor of California [[Arnold Schwarzenegger]]; [[Mayor of London]] [[Sadiq Khan]]; author and journalist [[Ta-Nehisi Coates]]; journalist [[Christiane Amanpour]]; rap artist/producer [[David Banner]], and film producer/directors [[Barry Jenkins]], [[Darren Aronofsky]] and [[Steven Spielberg]]. Actor and comedian [[Bill Murray]] appeared at several unofficial functions during SXSW. Major performers during SXSW Music included [[Tinashe]], [[Rae Sremmurd]], [[Rita Coolidge]], [[Salt-N-Pepa]] and [[Khalid (singer)|Khalid]]. There was an apparent increased emphasis on locally based performers, international acts and relative unknowns. New games announced during the 2018 SXSW Gaming Expo included ''[[Sonic Mania|Sonic Mania Plus]]''.{{Cite news|url=https://www.bleedingcool.com/2018/03/16/sonic-mania-plus-announced-at-sxsw-with-physical-edition-and-new-characters/|title=Sonic Mania Plus Announced at SXSW with Physical Edition and New Characters|date=2018-03-16|work=Bleeding Cool News And Rumors|access-date=2018-03-17|language=en-US}} At the SXSW Gaming Awards (held March 17), the award for Game of the Year went to ''[[The Legend of Zelda: Breath of the Wild]].''{{Cite news|url=https://www.512tech.com/technology/pubg-and-legend-zelda-take-top-prizes-2018-sxsw-gaming-awards/aP9g20knujXrF5T2CfxcbJ/|title='Legend of Zelda' and 'PUBG' top winners at SXSW Gaming Awards|last=|first=|date=|work=512tech (Austin American-Statesman)|access-date=2018-03-18}} Films that premiered at the 2018 South By Southwest Film Festival include ''[[A Quiet Place (film)|A Quiet Place]],'' ''[[Blockers (film)|Blockers]]'' and ''[[Ready Player One (film)|Ready Player One]]''.{{cite web |title=SXSW Unveils 2018 Festival Lineup, With John Krasinski’s ‘A Quiet Place’ Opening-Night Film |url=http://deadline.com/2018/01/sxsw-2018-south-by-southwest-features-lineup-john-krasinksi-a-quiet-place-1202274955/ |publisher=''Deadline'' |first=Dino-Ray |last=Ramos |date=January 31, 2018}} Films that had their U.S. premiere include ''[[Final Portrait]]'' and ''[[Who We Are Now]]''. TV series that previewed include ''[[Barry (TV series)|Barry]]'', ''[[Krypton (TV series)|Krypton]]'', ''[[The Last O.G.]]'' and ''[[Cloak & Dagger (TV series)|Cloak & Dagger]]''.{{cite web |title=Marvel's 'Cloak & Dagger' holds watch party at SXSW |url=http://www.kvue.com/article/life/events/sxsw/marvels-cloak-dagger-holds-watch-party-at-sxsw/269-527699516 |publisher=KVUE |authors=Drew Knight, Daysi Yeates |date=March 11, 2018}} To promote the second season of the HBO series [[Westworld (TV series)|''Westworld'']], a recreation of the show's fictional Western "town" of Sweetwater was built on two acres of open land just outside Austin. Fans took shuttles to the site, which was dressed in the Old West style, with over 60 actors playing the parts of the android "hosts".{{Cite news|url=http://www.adweek.com/brand-marketing/inside-hbo-and-giant-spoons-massive-immersive-westworld-activation-at-sxsw/|title=Inside HBO and Giant Spoon's Massive Immersive Westworld Activation at SXSW|access-date=2018-03-11|language=en-US}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.cnet.com/news/hbo-brings-westworld-to-sxsw/|title='Westworld's gritty western fantasy comes to life at SXSW|date=2018-03-09|work=CNET|access-date=2018-03-11|language=en}} SXSW 2018 coincided with a [[Austin serial bombings|string of bombings in Austin]], which had begun on March 2 and ended on March 21, when the presumed perpetrator, Mark Anthony Conditt, blew himself up after being discovered by police.{{Cite news|url=https://www.statesman.com/news/crime--law/the-suspect-family-mark-conditt-grieving-and-shock/CQUCcXNJ9nb2iFs8sSq0pK/|title=THE SUSPECT: Family of Mark A.
